review.title: INAUT, a Controlled Language for the French Coast Pilot Books Instructions nautiques
review.abstract: We describe INAUT, a controlled natural language dedicated to collaborative update of a knowledge base on maritime navigation and to automatic generation of coast pilot books (Instructions nautiques) of the French National Hydrographic and Oceanographic Service SHOM. INAUT is based on French language and abundantly uses georeferenced entities. After describing the structure of the overall system, giving details on the language and on its generation, and discussing the three major applications of INAUT (document production, interaction with ENCs and collaborative updates of the knowledge base), we conclude with future extensions and open problems.

sections.heading: 3 The controlled languages INAUT and LitINAUT
sections.text: INAUT is a controlled language with a fairly large vocabulary (based on the existing Instructions nautiques corpus), but with a simple syntax given by the following grammar: S сNP VP NP сmodif det det NN | det NN | NN сadj adj NN VP Ñ verb NP | verb NP PP Ñ prep det NN | prep NNN, where symbols in small caps are terminal, all nouns belong to LI (the set of lexical references for instances of K) and to V (the set of values for attributes of K), all verbs belong to LRS YLRRC, all adjectives belong to V, and modifiers, determinants and prepositions belong to a closed list. The verb, always in the 3rd person or infinitive, can be active or passive. In most cases it is possible to change the voice of the verb, which implies a permutation of the verb.

sections.heading: 5 Interaction with ENCs
sections.text: As mentioned in the introduction, the Instructions nautiques are defined as a supplement to the maps, especially to the ENCs. Therefore, it is important to define the interactions between K and ENCs via INAUT. By specifying an area of interest on an ENC (for example, by drawing a zone on a touch screen), the user can obtain LitINAUT text in return. Automatic generation of this text has the advantage of (a) being limited to the area of interest specified by the user; (b) adapting it to local conditions, e.g. time of day (some relationships or attributes in K may be time-dependent) or meteorological conditions or parameters of the user's ship (size, tonnage, etc.); (c) current, as other users can constantly provide new information. To provide adaptable LitINAUT text, we first position the area U specified by the user in A and thus in G. sections.heading: 6 Collaborative updates of the knowledge base
sections.text: In order to achieve this goal, INAUT is used as a tool for collaborative updates. In fact, INAUT was conceived as an optimal compromise between usability (since contributors a priori do not have KM knowledge) and formality (since the knowledge base is fed directly by the incoming data). In order to make the system more robust, we validate on two levels. First, on the lexical and syntactic level: A web interface analyzes segments written in INAUT and validates them. In case of errors, it provides corrective information. Second, on the semantic level: A human controller monitors incoming INAUT data, which is automatically fed into the knowledge base depending on the confidence level of the contributors (with the possibility of making the change retroactively) or stored in a waiting list until manual validation.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusion and future work
sections.text: We have described the controlled natural language INAUT (and its variant LitINAUT), which is used for updating the maritime knowledge base SHOM, for the automatic generation of instructions nautical documents and for interacting with ENCs. One of our plans is to extend INAUT to a QA system. This requires the extension of INAUT to include questions and the increased use of the concept hierarchy. Another extension deals with the problem of hazardousness. In fact, one of the objectives of Instructions nautiques is to warn the navigator of possible hazards. Ideally, the ENC should automatically send questions about hazards to the knowledge base concerning the current position of the ship and various external conditions, and in case of a positive response warn the navigator by all means. Special NLG techniques can then be used, as the communicative objective is not simply to inform, but to alert.
